splashTitle:
Level 3
Advanced on-road cycle training

Select Start to begin.

title: Introduction
body:
Welcome to this module on advanced on-road cycle training, which is often an integral part of the work that instructors carry out. Being able to ride in more complex environments opens up a range of new cycling opportunities and promotes positive behaviour change. This module will guide you as an instructor to help riders develop the knowledge, skills and confidence they require.

Let’s hear a little more about the module from Megan Giglia of The Bikeability Trust.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video.

title: The aim of the module
body:
The aim of the module is to support and empower you as a cycling instructor to deliver effective training in advanced on-road environments in line with the delivery guidance and the National Standard for Cycle Training. This includes training on multi-lane roads and complex junctions, where traffic volume and speed are often higher.

This training module is for all instructors currently delivering, or planning to deliver, advanced on-road training, namely:

  • existing instructors seeking to understand current good practice
  • instructors who are undertaking the Level 2 Award in Instructing Cycle Training (L2AICT)
Please note: In this module, the term ‘advanced on-road’ refers to training environments that could also be described as ‘Bikeability Level 3’.
instruction: Scroll down to continue.

_graphic.alt: An instructor cycling on a busy road

title: Why advanced on-road training?
body: Advanced on-road training is essential for supporting and giving riders the skills and confidence to make journeys by cycle in any environment where cycling is permitted. The training builds on previously acquired skills to enable riders to cycle in a range of environments.

title: Learning objectives
body: There are five learning objectives for this module. By the end of the module you should:
instruction: Select the ‘+’ button to find out what these are.

_items.content: understand how cycle training in advanced on-road environments links to the National Standard for Cycle Training and delivery guidance
be able to assess rider readiness and build rider confidence for advanced on-road training
be able to use different approaches for delivering advanced on-road training, and plan sessions that involve a smooth transition into more complex activities
have the knowledge and confidence to deliver training in advanced environments including multi-lane roads and complex junctions, where traffic volume and speed are often higher
understand good practice considerations for inclusivity in cycle training and for carrying out risk benefit assessments (RBAs)

title: Up next
body: Let’s now look at how advanced on-road cycle training is underpinned by The Bikeability Trust delivery guidance and the National Standard for Cycle Training.

_links.title: Delivery guidance and the National Standard

title: The delivery guidance
body:
When planning, delivering, reviewing and adapting advanced on-road cycle training, you should use The Bikeability Trust’s three delivery guidance documents, which are underpinned by the National Standard.

You can find these documents under the Resources tab.
instruction: Select the images for an overview of each document.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrow for an overview of each document.

_graphic.alt: The National Standard for Cycle Training cover page in the centre with the three delivery guidance documents – Cycle Training Delivery Guide, Cycle Activity Templates and Ride Guide – in a connected circle around it

_items.title: Cycle Training Delivery Guide
_items.body: A comprehensive guide that provides you with the information you need to teach cycle training in diverse environments.
_items.strapline: Cycle Training Delivery Guide

_graphic.alt: Front cover of the Cycle Training Delivery Guide

_items.title: Cycle Activity Templates
_items.body: These Templates are effectively sample session plans that show activities you can use to teach riders to cycle in diverse environments. The advanced on-road training content is covered in the last seven Cycle Activity Templates.
_items.strapline: Cycle Activity Templates

_graphic.alt: Front cover of the Cycle Activity Templates

_items.title: Ride Guide
_items.body: This is a description of cycling in a variety of scenarios, both on and off road, and includes topics such as how to perform certain manoeuvres when cycling. If you need to gain further understanding on good cycling practice on how to pass queuing traffic, ride in bus lanes or negotiate multi-lane junctions, then the Ride Guide is an essential resource to help you clarify understanding.
_items.strapline: Ride Guide

_graphic.alt: Front cover of the Ride Guide

title: The National Standard for Cycle Training
displayTitle: The National Standard for Cycle Training
body:
Of the six Roles in the National Standard, Role 4 contains several statements that relate to riding in more complex environments.

Take a few minutes to read the National Standard, in particular Role 4, and imagine you are about to ride in a busy, complex on-road environment.

You can find the National Standard in the Resources tab.
instruction: Enter your points in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content: Your notes have been saved! Compare the points you have listed with those shown below. Scroll down to continue.

_activity.title: The National Standard for Cycle Training
_activity.body: Take a few minutes to read the National Standard, in particular Role 4, and imagine you are about to ride in a busy, complex on-road environment.

_items.question: What would be some of the most important skills and competencies required for cycling there?

title: The relevant skills and competencies highlighted in Role 4 of the National Standard
instruction: Select the arrow to learn more about the relevant skills and competencies highlighted in Role 4 of the National Standard.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrow to learn more about the relevant skills and competencies highlighted in Role 4 of the National Standard.

_items.title: The National Standard for Cycle Training
_items.body: Here are some of the important skills and competencies in Role 4 of the National Standard.
_items.strapline: The National Standard for Cycle Training

_graphic.alt: Front cover of the National Standard

_items.title: Communicate with other road users
_items.body:
More complex road environments require the ability and confidence to ride and share the road safely and responsibly with other road users.

The first Element covers the skill to be able to communicate effectively with other road users using a routine.
_items.strapline: Communicate with other road users

_graphic.alt: A clip of Role 4 from The National Standard with Role 4: Ride safely and responsibly in the traffic system and Element 4.1.1: Communicate with other road users highlighted.

_items.title: Cooperate with and respect other road users
_items.body:
Element 4.1.2 covers the ability to interact with other road users in a variety of different settings and scenarios.

“You cycle with a positive and collaborative approach to sharing the road. Through actively and positively interacting with other road users, you help to contribute to a co-operative culture.”

(Cycle Training Delivery Guide, p. 15)
_items.strapline: Cooperate with and respect other road users

_graphic.alt: A clip of Role 4 from The National Standard with Element 4.1.2: Cooperate with and respect other road users highlighted.

_items.title: Identify and respond to hazards
_items.body:
The ability to deal with hazards is covered in Element 4.2.1, including being able to continually scan the cycling environment and anticipate, evaluate and appropriately respond to possible hazards.

“Whether you’re riding in the park, on a segregated cycle lane or on the road, you are sharing space with others. This means being aware of your surroundings and co-operating with those around you. Staying aware and alert enables you to identify and respond to hazards and the actions of others. It lets you anticipate potential problems before they even take place.”

(Ride Guide, p. 23)
_items.strapline: Identify and respond to hazards

_graphic.alt: A clip of Role 4 from The National Standard with Element 4.2.1: Identify and respond to hazards highlighted.

_items.title: Ride assertively
_items.body:
Riding assertively is especially important to advanced on-road training. You’ll help riders to use primary position in new and busy environments, remaining calm as they interact with more people on their journey.

Two important points in Element 4.2.2 relate to this:

  • being able to create and maintain a safe riding space, through scanning the space ahead and behind and by positioning yourself for maximum visibility to others
  • managing your physical and emotional state when cycling
_items.strapline: Ride assertively

_graphic.alt: A clip of Role 4 from The National Standard with Element 4.2.2: Ride assertively highlighted.

title: Up next
body:
How do you know if a rider is ready for advanced on-road training?

Let’s explore this further in the next topic.

title: How do you know if a rider is ready?
displayTitle: How do you know if a rider is ready?
body: What must riders demonstrate before riding in more advanced cycling environments?
instruction: Select the correct options or options and then select Check answer.

_items.text: Being able to control their cycles and ride instinctively
Show evidence of completing prior training
Riding at the same pace as other road users

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Yes, that’s right.

Before riding in more advanced environments, riders must be able to control their cycles and navigate less challenging junctions competently. If you are delivering Bikeability Level 3, this means that your riders must be competent at Level 1 and 2 before you start Level 3. You don’t need them to produce a certificate or other evidence of their prior training (though such information may be helpful). The speed that a rider can cycle at should not be a barrier to attending advanced on-road training but should be considered when planning activities.

Now close this window and scroll down to continue.

_incorrect.final:
That’s still not completely correct.

Take a look at the correct answers. Before riding in more advanced environments, riders must be able to control their cycles and navigate less challenging junctions competently. If you are delivering Bikeability Level 3, this means that your riders must be competent at Level 1 and 2 before you start Level 3. You don’t need them to produce a certificate or other evidence of their prior training (though such information may be helpful). The speed that a rider can cycle at should not be a barrier to attending advanced on-road training but should be considered when planning activities.

Now close this window and scroll down to continue.

title: Assessing rider performance
body: You must observe riders cycling in both off-road (traffic-free) and on-road environments before they ride in more complex environments. This will help consolidate prior learning, build confidence and serve as an initial assessment opportunity where you can assess their readiness for more complex training activities.
instruction: Scroll down to continue.

title: Off-road assessment
body:
Consider this scenario.

You need to assess – in an off-road (traffic-free) environment – your riders’ control skills in preparation for cycling on the road together.
instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content: Your notes have been saved! Compare your thoughts with the suggestions below. Scroll down to continue.

_activity.title: Off-road assessment
_activity.body: You need to assess – in an off-road (traffic-free) environment – your riders’ control skills in preparation for cycling on the road together.

_items.question: How can you do this efficiently to enable your riders to begin their on-road training in a timely manner?

title: • cont.
body: You can take a few minutes in an off-road (traffic-free) environment to deliver a short activity where you check the core competencies. You could use a simple circuit and ask riders to ride around it, taking turns as the leader and regularly changing direction as you call out things for them to do.

title: On-road assessment
body: On-road assessment is essential before transitioning to more challenging environments. It may have been a long time since riders attended prior training, and the sites to be used in the advanced on-road training may be significantly more challenging than what they have experienced before.
instruction: Enter your notes in the boxes below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content: Your notes have been saved! Compare your thoughts with the suggestions below. Scroll down to continue.

_activity.title: On-road assessment
_activity.body: On-road assessment is essential before transitioning to more challenging environments. It may have been a long time since riders attended prior training, and the sites to be used in the advanced on-road training may be significantly more challenging than what they have experienced before.

_items.question: How might you support your riders to recap what they’ve learnt in prior training?
What on-road activities could you carry out to enable you to assess your riders’ performance and readiness to carry out more complex training activities?

title: • cont.
instruction: Select each image for suggestions of on-road reassessment activities.

_items.leftAlt: Instructor behind a rider in primary position passing parked cars
_items.rightText:
Circuit-based activities
You can assess riders’ application of the four key skills (observation, positioning, communication, priorities) as they carry out circuit-based activities where they attempt various left and right turns on single-lane roads and junctions with progressively busier traffic flows. By cycling behind your riders, you will be able to assess them on the move and coach them along the way.

_items.leftAlt: Instructor observing a rider from the side of the road
_items.rightText:
Point-to-point independent riding activities
If a more focused assessment is needed, you could ask riders to recap point-to-point independent riding activities with you assessing their cycling from the roadside. See the Cycle Activity Templates for more ideas.

title: Checking on-road skills
body: Watch this video for an example of an instructor coaching and checking riders’ on-road skills.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video.

title: Building rider confidence
body:
Riders embarking on advanced on-road training will sometimes feel nervous about the prospect of encountering higher traffic flows or faster moving traffic in their training sessions.

It is important you understand and carefully respond to these concerns or anxieties to ensure your riders get the most out of their training and their cycling in general. An ability to stay calm will be fundamental to enabling your riders to cycle confidently in diverse environments.
instruction: Scroll down to continue.

title: How could you support this rider to build their confidence?
displayTitle: How could you support this rider to build their confidence?
body:
On meeting a rider for their advanced on-road training, it becomes apparent that, despite them having already completed prior training (Level 2 Bikeability), they are nervous about the prospect of cycling in busier and faster traffic. They also say that they have previously panicked when encountering traffic on the road.

What could you do to support them to build their confidence and to enable them to enjoy their advanced on-road training?
instruction: Select the correct options or options and then select Check answer.

_items.text: Use positive language in the session and regularly check in to ask the rider how they are feeling at various points in the session
Ensure they are aware of their rights to ride assertively when needed and highlight the relevant Highway Code rules where this is helpful
Avoid asking any questions relating to their confidence levels and simply focus on the skills they need for advanced on-road cycling
Offer to ride with them for point-to-point riding activities if these are being attempted

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Yes, those are all good options.

It is important to recognise how riders are feeling to give them the necessary support to overcome their fears, so they can approach their training and cycling positively. Take a look at some other suggestions below on what you could do.

Now close this window and scroll down to continue.

_incorrect.notFinal:
Not quite.

Select Reset and have another go.
_incorrect.final:
That’s still not quite correct.

Have a look at the correct answers. It is important to recognise how riders are feeling and give them the necessary support to overcome their fears, so they can approach their training and cycling positively. Take a look at some other suggestions below on what you could do.

Now close this window and scroll down to continue.

title: Different ways to enhance a rider’s confidence
body: There are different ways to enhance a rider’s confidence.
instruction: Scroll down to find out more.

_items.title: Recap
_items.body: Incorporate any recap/reassessment activities if these are needed. Practice and repetition can help to build confidence.

_items.title: Plan a suitable journey
_items.body:
Ensure that the planned journey is suitable for the rider. Carefully consider their current cycling ability and allow for progression at a suitable pace rather than sudden jumps in complexity from one activity to the next.

You could also integrate the rider’s specific cycling goals into their training. If they aspire to cycle to work, you could include parts of their future commute. This makes the training useful and increases rider engagement

_items.title: Use a routine-based approach
_items.body: Consider promoting a routine-based approach to cycling that breaks down actions or manoeuvres into shorter sequences that are easier to remember, always underpinned by independent decision-making.

_items.title: Highlight the benefit of communication
_items.body: Explain how communication with other road users can enhance confidence as it can lead to them communicating positively in return. This creates a feeling of being in control and equality among road users. Examples of communication include eye contact, smiling, positive body language and thanking other road users.

_items.title: Adjust your approach
_items.body:
When necessary, explore options such as dismounting and walking certain sections of a route, or planning a quieter route.

“It is normal to feel nervous sometimes when cycling. It is perfectly fine to pull over and pause a journey so you can regain your composure. When planning your journey, you should choose a route that reflects your cycling ability and confidence.”

(Cycle Training Delivery Guide, page 14.)

title: Dealing with nerves
body: Watch this video for an example of what you could say or suggest to a rider who is nervous about riding in a more challenging environment.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video for some ideas.

title: Positive relationships on the road
body:
You can teach your riders to treat each interaction with other people on the road as a brief relationship, where they can use positive facial expressions and body language to help build rapport.

Watch this video, which shows how a rider interacts with other road users in order to build positive relationships.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video for some ideas.

title: Up next
body: In the next topic, we will explore the typical activities you will teach in advanced on-road training and some strategies you can use.

instruction: Select the home button to return to the module contents screen or the forward arrow to move straight to the next topic.

_links.title: Delivery guidance and the National Standard

title: What you will teach
body:
Remember that training activities need to be planned in a rider-centred manner and only be attempted or progressed when riders are ready. As your riders’ skills and confidence grow, so should the degree of challenge. This is where your formative assessment of their riding will help you ensure that the rate of progression is suitable and as rider-centred as possible.

What advanced on-road skills will you be teaching?
instruction: Select the arrow to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Start with transitionary on-road activities
_items.body:
Advanced on-road training will typically start with transitionary on-road activities on single-lane roads before progressing onto more complex activities.

Ideas for these transitionary activities can be found in Cycle Activity Template: Riding in more complex environments.

These activities may be integrated into your rider assessment strategy that we covered earlier, or may be carried out separately as standalone activities when you are already familiar with your riders’ cycling ability.
_items.strapline: Start with transitionary on-road activities

_graphic.alt: Instructor cycling behind two riders in a cycle lane

_items.title: Advance to more complex activities
_items.body:
Once you assess your riders as ready, they can then advance to more complex advanced on-road activities, like those set out in the Cycle Activity Templates:

  • using traffic lights
  • passing queuing traffic
  • using cycling infrastructure
  • using multi-lane roads
  • using multi-lane roundabouts
  • being aware of driver blind spots
  • sharing bus lanes
  • riding on roads with a speed limit above 30mph
_items.strapline: Advance to more complex activities

_graphic.alt: Rider cycling behind a bus in a bus/cycle lane

_items.title: Be flexible in your delivery
_items.body:
The Cycle Activity Templates show a suggested order for the delivery of the advanced on-road activities, which are sometimes combined onto single session plans. However, remember that you can be flexible in how you deliver training, which should be as rider-centred as possible.

For example, Cycle Activity Template: Using traffic lights and passing queuing traffic combines two activities, which you may prefer to keep separate. You may assess that your riders are ready to negotiate junctions controlled by traffic lights but are not yet ready to learn how to filter slow-moving or standstill traffic, so you will need to adapt the training accordingly.
_items.strapline: Be flexible in your delivery

_graphic.alt: Two riders stopped at traffic lights

title: Strategies for delivery
body:
Effective advanced on-road delivery will involve different coaching strategies that should be applied in a rider-centred way to achieve the best possible training outcomes. Training will normally involve a combination of:

  • buddy riding where riders carry out longer journeys
  • point-to-point independent riding activities
Both approaches – longer journey-based activities or shorter point-to-point independent riding activities – will often require discussions by the roadside (where necessary accompanied by an instructor demonstration) to ensure your riders understand the important coaching points. As always, when your riders are away from their cycles, you should aim for high levels of active learning, with your riders cycling as soon as possible, so they can learn through practice!

For more information on active learning, you can visit the relevant section in the Cycle Training Delivery Guide under the Resources tab.

Let’s now look at these two main approaches for delivering advanced on-road training activities.

_graphic.alt: Instructor talking with two riders on the side of a road

title: Buddy riding
body:
Buddy-riding activities will see you support riders to carry out longer journeys by cycle.

They may include circuits involving several junctions, or longer journeys where riders practise a specific journey to school or work, and you take breaks along the way to discuss and reflect on learning points.

_graphic.alt: Instructor cycling behind two riders approaching a multi-lane roundabout

title: • Instructor and two riders using buddy riding as a strategy
body: This video shows an instructor and two riders using buddy riding as a strategy. Take note of how the instructor approaches it each time.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video.

title: • Instructor with a single rider using a different approach
body: This example shows the same instructor with a single rider using a different approach.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video.

_items.rightText: You ride behind the group to keep riders in sight and dynamically move up alongside them to offer verbal prompts and coaching along the route when necessary, highlighting when the four key skills are needed.

title: How could you enhance the learning experience for these riders? (Continued)
displayTitle: How could you enhance the learning experience for these riders?
body: You are delivering advanced on-road training to five riders with a co-instructor using a buddy-riding approach. Here is a picture showing you both moving the group in a more passive fashion.

title: What strategies could you use to enhance the riders’ active learning experience?

_message.content: Your notes have been saved! Compare your thoughts with the suggestions below. Scroll down to continue.

_activity.title: How could you enhance the learning experience for these riders?
_activity.body: You are delivering advanced on-road training to five riders with a co-instructor using a buddy-riding approach. Here is a picture showing you both moving the group in a more passive fashion.

_items.question: What strategies could you use to enhance the riders’ active learning experience?

title: • Here are some ideas ...
body: Here are some ideas of how to progress the buddy-riding approach in this situation.
instruction: Select each heading to learn more.

_items.title: Integrate with the group
_items.body: The front instructor cycles behind the first one or two riders, or in the middle of the group, to promote active learning and support where needed.

_graphic.alt: Five riders with one instructor cycling behind the first two riders and a rear instructor behind the last three riders

_items.title: Positioning at the rear
_items.body: You deliberately exert less ‘control’ over the group from the back and give riders more space and freedom to make their own decisions.

_graphic.alt: Five riders riding doubled up with one instructor doubled with the first rider at the front and the rear instructor riding at a distance behind the last pair of riders.

_items.title: Splitting the group
_items.body: Split the larger group into two, with each group cycling completely separately from one another, and then reconvening by the roadside at appropriate points along the journey. In this case, each instructor will again normally cycle behind each group of riders, dynamically moving alongside them when necessary.

_graphic.alt: One instructor cycling behind three riders and another instructor behind two riders in separate groups

title: Good practice example: Observation and anticipation
displayTitle: Good practice example: Observation and anticipation
body:
Being able to carry out continuous observations, and to anticipate and think about what comes next on one’s journey, is an important skill when cycling on the road. One simple way to promote this when you cycle behind riders can be through regularly asking, “What comes next?”.

This can prompt your riders to carry out their observations and apply the four key skills whenever they are cycling.

_graphic.alt: Light bulb icon

title: What are the advantages of buddy riding?
displayTitle: What are the advantages of buddy riding?
body: Take a look at the following statements and decide which accurately describe the benefits of buddy riding.
instruction: Select the correct options or options and then select Check answer.

_items.text: It provides riders the opportunity to make supported and independent decisions rather than simply following.
Buddy-riding activities enable more cycling time where riders can learn on the move and experience a real sense of a journey.
Having an instructor at the rear of the group means the riders do not need to check behind them as the instructor can do this.
Splitting into smaller groups when working with two instructors gives more riders the opportunity to lead.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Yes, that’s correct.

Remember that the aim is to facilitate active learning and help riders make their own decisions with instructor support only when necessary. There are various ways you can enhance independent decision-making when riding with riders. For example, even if an instructor is cycling behind a rider or group, the riders should still be responsible for looking behind and communicating with other road users, just as they would do if cycling alone.

Now close this window and scroll down to continue.

_incorrect.notFinal:
That’s not correct.

Select Reset and have another go.
_incorrect.final:
That’s still not quite correct.

Have a look at the correct answers. Remember that the aim is to facilitate active learning and help riders make their own decisions with instructor support only when necessary. There are various ways you can enhance independent decision-making when riding with riders. For example, even if an instructor is cycling behind a rider or group, the riders should still be responsible for looking behind and communicating with other road users, just as they would do if cycling alone.

Now close this window and scroll down to continue.

title: Advantages and disadvantages of buddy riding
displayTitle: Advantages and disadvantages of buddy riding
body: Take a look at some more advantages of buddy riding as well as a few disadvantages.
instruction: Scroll down to find out more.

_items.title: Advantages
_items.body:
• riding greater distances can enable your riders to cycle to various places of interest along the route and to practise future commutes
  • longer distances enable you to continually assess your riders’ performance and to support them through verbal coaching at the same time as cycling (learning through doing)
  • if you are working with another instructor, splitting into two smaller groups reduces the likelihood of the whole group getting ‘split’ at junctions

_items.title: Disadvantages
_items.body:
• cycling behind riders can obstruct their view of what is behind them – where appropriate, on most roads, you can avoid this by dropping back or positioning yourself behind and slightly to the left of the last rider; this will enable them to see behind clearly
  • unlike point-to-point independent riding activities where you observe from the roadside, your riders will never be cycling alone when performing buddy-riding activities – you will always be riding in the proximity of them
  • some riders may simply copy what others are doing in the group – reiterate the need for all riders to make independent decisions when cycling all together
  • certain riders may feel added pressure when being tasked with leading a group

title: Making an activity feel like a real-life journey
displayTitle: Making an activity feel like a real-life journey
body:
You are delivering a buddy-riding activity with two riders. This activity is limited to negotiating a roundabout from various directions and linking up the journey through U-turns. You want this activity to feel like a real-life journey for the riders.

How might you do this?
instruction: Select the arrow to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Adapt language
_items.body: On approaching the roundabout, rather than asking the riders to “Take the first exit”, use language like, “Take us to the park”, or “Take us back to the school”. This will help the riders conceptualise the idea of journeys by cycle that involve specific destinations.
_items.strapline: Adapt language

_items.title: Show a map
_items.body: Immediately before the exercise, bring out a map to show the route that will be ridden. Be aware of any policies related to phone use within the setting in which you are working.
_items.strapline: Show a map

_items.title: Give both riders a chance to lead
_items.body: Ensure both riders have the opportunity to lead at the front and that they support and communicate with each other as they would do if riding to school together.
_items.strapline: Give both riders a chance to lead

title: Point-to-point independent riding activities
body: These activities, much like in earlier on-road (Level 2 Bikeability) training, will see your riders carry out shorter point-to-point journeys as part of a longer journey, to tackle a particular site, junction or piece of cycling infrastructure. They will always take place in sight of you or your co-instructor, who will usually be observing by the roadside.

title: • An example ...
body: This video shows an example of a point-to-point independent riding activity.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video.

title: Advantages and disadvantages of independent riding activities
displayTitle: Advantages and disadvantages of independent riding activities
body: What are the benefits and downsides of point-to-point independent riding activities? Look at these statements and decide whether they are true or false.
instruction: Select ‘True’ or ‘False’ for each option.

_items.content: Independent riding limits opportunities for cycling longer distances.
_items.feedback: This is particularly true when training larger groups.

_items.content: It can be difficult to provide immediate feedback to riders.
_items.feedback: You can provide immediate feedback and let them have another go. Should an adult rider consent, then taking a video on your phone of them riding is a fantastic way to give feedback afterwards too.

_items.content: They can be less helpful for practising future commutes or journeys.
_items.feedback: It can be very helpful for riders to practise independently riding through specific on-road junctions or sites, such as ones that they will use in a future commute.

_items.content: Riders develop greater independence as they typically ride without you.
_items.feedback: Riding without an instructor close by encourages independent decision-making.

_feedbacks.content: We have seen there are both advantages and disadvantages to point-to-point independent riding and buddy approaches. It is your job as a cycling instructor to decide which approach is better for the rider, situation and the aims you are trying to achieve.

We have seen there are both advantages and disadvantages to point-to-point independent riding and buddy approaches. It is your job as a cycling instructor to decide which approach is better for the rider, situation and the aims you are trying to achieve.

title: Up next
body: Now that we’ve covered strategies for delivering advanced on-road training, let’s move on to the next topic: How to plan the advanced on-road training session and how to transition into more complex activities.

instruction: Select the home button to return to the module contents screen or the forward arrow to move straight to the next topic.

title: The pre-ride discussion
body:
Training should start with a pre-ride discussion – ideally away from cycles – where you and your riders discuss and plan the journey to be taken during the session and the specific training activities to be covered. The training activities will need to reflect your riders’ cycling ability, and you should consider including scenarios that they will encounter in future. You can use the Cycle Activity Templates for the session-planning process where this is helpful.

Remember you will need to be flexible and work with what you have and don’t always need to stick to the order and combination of activities as is presented in the Templates.

Be careful not to spend too much time on the pre-ride planning activities – the majority of the training time should be for actual cycling.
instruction: Scroll down to continue.

title: • An example ...
body: Watch this video for an example of an instructor having a pre-ride discussion with riders.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video.

_activity.body: Using your observations from the video and ideas of your own, make a note of …

_items.question: … how you might help your riders plan the journey they will attempt in the session and what questions you could ask

title: • Some points you could discuss ...
body: Here are some points you could discuss when planning the cycle training session with riders.
instruction: Select each image to find out more.

_items.rightText:
The route
  • work together to plan a route by looking at maps or electronic planners, or reviewing a route that has already been prepared by your riders as a homework exercise prior to the session
  • choose a route that is as useful as possible for your riders, such as integrating aspects of a future commute to and from school or work
  • refer to the route later in the session, such as when you stop to consult maps by the roadside

Possible questions
  • How much time do you have?
  • How fast do you want to get there?
  • What are the advantages of this route?

_items.leftAlt: Finger frame icon with smiley face
_items.rightText:
Riders’ feelings and needs
  • find out how ready they feel to cycle in more complex environments
  • ensure the journey reflects your riders’ cycling experience, ability and individual needs – the most suitable training activities should be incorporated into the journey
  • you may or may not wish to include quieter routes in the session, but you should draw to your riders’ attention the benefits of planning and riding quieter and enjoyable routes

Possible questions
  • How do you feel about this route?
  • What roads are you comfortable using?
  • What do you want to learn?

You can learn how to consider and plan for any additional needs in The Bikeability Trust Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND) training module.

_items.leftAlt: Icon of a person cycling with helmet and backpack
_items.rightText:
Learning styles
  • find out if there are specific ways riders prefer to learn and how they would like you to work with them
  • remember, different riders may have different learning styles, and you may need to include a combination in the session to meet their needs
Learning styles are covered in the ‘Teaching, learning and assessing’ e-learning module if you would like to explore this further.

What to take
  • discuss what items may be needed for the journey, such as a mobile phone, drink, tools, a cycle lock and clothing
  • check how these will be safely carried, such as in a backpack

Possible questions
  • What might you need with you?
  • What about the weather?
  • How will you carry these safely?

Be flexible
  • you need to work with the environment and cycling infrastructure in the area, adapting activities as needed
  • planning will be influenced by rider needs, the environment and your RBA, and you and your riders may need to be open to unexpected changes or deviate from the plan

Signpost riders
  • refer your riders to places where they can obtain further cycling-related information such as local infrastructure maps, cycling groups and organisations

title: Ensuring inclusivity
body:
Advanced on-road training must be delivered in a rider-centred and inclusive fashion that embraces, as far as possible, riders of all abilities.

Think about this scenario and answer the question that follows.

You are planning a session for two riders who have additional needs. One of the riders has cerebral palsy and will be using a hand-powered adapted cycle that is wider than most cycles, and the other rider will be using a recumbent, which is low to the ground. They are both experienced in using these adapted cycles. Both riders have restricted mobility that affects their ability to look behind when cycling.
instruction: Enter your thoughts in the boxes below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_activity.body: You are planning a session for two riders who have additional needs. One of the riders has cerebral palsy and will be using a hand-powered adapted cycle that is wider than most cycles, and the other rider will be using a recumbent, which is low to the ground. They are both experienced in using these adapted cycles. Both riders have restricted mobility that affects their ability to look behind when cycling.

_items.question: What inclusion strategies will you need to think about when planning this session?

title: • Some potential accessibility considerations ...
body:
Here are some potential accessibility considerations to think about.

You can further enhance your knowledge of how to deliver inclusive training by attending The Bikeability Trust’s SEND online training module.
instruction: Select each heading to learn more.

_items.title: Suitable ratios
_items.body: Ensure the instructor-to-rider ratios are suitable and work with another instructor to have a 2:2 ratio if needed.

_items.title: Accessible routes and infrastructure
_items.body: When planning the route with the riders, ensure it only features accessible infrastructure and routes that are wide enough for both riders and their adapted cycles, and it considers the speed differential between the riders and other road users.

_items.title: Position on the road
_items.body: Ensure both riders are supported to adopt the primary position when necessary and to take up sufficient space on the road to deter road users behind from hazardous overtaking.

_items.title: Increase visibility
_items.body: Ensure that both riders, particularly the rider using the recumbent, are aware that they may not be easily visible to other road users due to being lower to the ground. Other strategies might include attaching flags and extra lights to the cycles, promoting more assertive riding positions when necessary, and having the riders sit in a car to observe how much other road users will see of them when they use their cycles.

_items.title: Install mirrors
_items.body: You could support the riders to install mirrors that are attached to their cycles so that they are more aware of other road users behind them.

title: Transitioning to more complex activities
body:
The advanced on-road training should factor in smooth levels of progression, rather than sudden jumps up in the complexity of activities.

The Cycle Activity Template: Riding in complex environments shares some ideas for how you can support your riders to transition to riding in more challenging environments.

title: • cont.
body:
From the REPPROC Principles (Cycle Training Delivery Guide)

  • riders experience more challenging cycling environments as their skills and confidence grow. Training is delivered in a logical way with activities and manoeuvres becoming more complex
  • once riders feel comfortable with a set of skills, they can be challenged further during the next round of activities
  • each rider can progress at their own pace and according to their learning needs

In this video, the instructor watches and encourages riders through a transitional activity where riders negotiate a road narrowing. This is a good example of previously learnt skills being practised in a more complex environment.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video.

This should be done using appropriate language and in a manner that is understood by your riders. Keep these types of questions in mind as you teach different activities.

title: Delivering advanced on-road activities
body:
The next section takes you on a journey carried out in an advanced on-road training session, integrating a range of activities.

Bear in mind that this journey is just one example. When you deliver advanced on-road training, you can combine any number of activities to do what is best for your riders. Some sites will provide opportunities for combining activities. For example, a multi-lane roundabout could involve passing queuing traffic and be controlled by traffic lights and even have some cycling infrastructure around it too. Use what you have and do not be afraid to link activities together.
instruction: Select each example to find out more.

_items.title: Using traffic lights and passing queuing traffic
Being aware of driver blind spots and sharing bus lanes
Riding on roads with a speed limit above 30mph

You can use and adapt these examples of advanced on-road cycling activities in your sessions, and you can find many more ideas in the Cycle Activity Templates under the Resources tab. Let’s now move on to the important topic of Risk Benefit Assessment (RBA).

title: Using traffic lights
body:
Most advanced on-road sessions will include negotiating junctions controlled by traffic lights.

Consider a scenario such as this and list some of the coaching points you would use to teach your riders.

_activity.title: Using traffic lights
_activity.body: Most advanced on-road sessions will include negotiating junctions controlled by traffic lights. Consider a scenario such as this and list some of the coaching points you would use to teach your riders.

_items.question: Think about how they approach the junction, what they do at the traffic lights and how they pass through the junction.

title: • cont.
body: Take a look at some coaching points you could use.
instruction: Scroll down to find out more.

_items.title: Approaching the junction
_items.body:
• on seeing the traffic lights up ahead, look back to see if there are any road users behind
  • if necessary, communicate the intention to move into the primary position, using eye contact and signalling if required
  • check if it is clear and move into the primary position if possible
  • look behind and in front to see if road users are planning to turn at the junction

_items.title: At the traffic lights
_items.body: • observe at the traffic lights and, on reaching the junction, adhere to the traffic-light phase, stopping before the stop line if required or continuing if this is permitted

_items.title: Passing through the junction
_items.body:
• when passing through the junction, look out for any hazards, or pedestrians crossing the road who have priority
  • make eye contact with other road users where helpful
  • after the junction, either continue in the primary position or look back over the left shoulder and, if it is clear, move back to the secondary position

title: Passing queuing traffic
body:
“One of the advantages of being on a cycle is that you can move past a traffic queue... You should always assess the environment and any potential hazards when deciding whether to filter.”

(Ride Guide page 55)

Watch this video, which shows some clips of a rider passing queuing traffic as they approach two junctions. As the video pauses and asks you questions, write down your answers to the questions in the box shown.

_items.instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content:
Your notes have been saved!

Select the arrow to continue with the video.

_items.question: What are important things to think about when deciding whether or not to filter here?

_items.instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content:
Your notes have been saved!

Compare your thoughts with these ideas:

  • for single lanes of queuing traffic, it will normally be better to filter on the right-hand side of the queuing traffic, but not always
  • on multi-lane roads with queuing traffic, it can be best to filter in between the two lanes, but again, not always
  • as this clip will show, the road soon widens into two lanes and there is not enough space to reach the front in between the two lanes. As there is enough time and space on the left-hand side to filter to the front, the rider sensibly (in this case) decides to use that side. If there had been insufficient time to get to the front, the cycle lane would normally be best avoided due to the possibility of road users behind overtaking and turning left at the junction
  • riders should usually adopt the primary position when riding through junctions. This helps to create and maintain a ‘safe riding space’ – in clear sight of others and preventing hazardous overtaking

Select the arrow to continue with the video.

_items.question: If riding to the front, which side would be best to filter on and why?
If there is space at the front, what position should riders use?

_items.instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content:
Your notes have been saved!

Here are some ideas to consider:

  • in this example, it is unclear when the lights will change and, in any case, the rider is already quite close to the front
  • in addition, due to the size of the queuing vehicles and lack of available space, and clear signs that road users in front are about to turn right, the rider makes the sensible decision to not filter any further and to wait in the traffic queue

    • Select the arrow to continue with the video.

_items.question: Why do you think the rider has chosen to wait here?

_items.instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content:
Your notes have been saved!

Consider this suggestion:

  • if passing vehicles that start to move, the space between two queuing road users normally expands when the traffic moves off, creating a sort of ‘concertina’ effect. This is the rider’s opportunity to make eye contact with the road user behind and to drop back into the traffic flow

    • Select the arrow to continue with the video.

_items.question: If the traffic starts to move off, what should the rider’s strategy be?

title: How could you deliver this activity?
displayTitle: How could you deliver this activity?
body: You want to cover the topic of filtering and are working alone with two riders in an environment with queuing traffic and junctions with traffic lights where the phases change quickly. This greatly increases the likelihood of riders becoming split.
instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content:
Your notes have been saved!

Here are some suggestions to compare your ideas with:

  • to give the riders the opportunity to practise filtering, deliver the activity as a point-to-point independent riding activity so that the riders are kept in sight by you observing and supporting them from the roadside
  • as a helpful way to promote active learning, have the riders attempt the activity one at a time with the other rider waiting and observing to review their peer’s attempt before having a go themselves
  • if you are riding as a group, remind the leading rider to check behind them regularly and ride at a speed that keeps the group together where possible

title: Multi-lane roads and roundabouts
body:
Negotiating multi-lane roads and junctions is an important part of advanced on-road training and can be delivered in a progressive manner where riders experience changing lanes on roads with increasing traffic and approaching or leaving multi-lane junctions in different directions.

This activity relates very closely to the National Standard concepts of ‘riding assertively’ and the need to ’create and maintain a safe riding space’.

Let’s now take a closer look at this activity.

You can also find ideas in the Cycle Activity Templates: Using multi-lane roads and Using multi-lane roundabouts.
instruction: Select the ‘+’ button for examples of different questions you could ask your riders.
content:
Priorities:

Q: How many roads are there at this multi-lane roundabout? Which is the main road?
A: There are four roads. The roundabout itself is the main road that has priority over all the others.

Q: On reaching the roundabout, which road users have priority?
A: Those already on the roundabout have priority as do others entering from the right.

_items.content:
Observation:

Q: Where do you need to look when negotiating this roundabout?
A: Look behind for any road users on the approach to the roundabout. On reaching the roundabout, look to the right for road users on the roundabout or those wishing to enter. As you cycle around the roundabout, look down the entry roads for any road users wishing to enter the roundabout. Check behind before changing lanes on the roundabout and before exiting.

Communication:

Q: Should you signal to road users behind you in advance of the roundabout?
A: If turning left (first exit) or right (third exit) from the roundabout, you should signal your intentions in advance of the roundabout.

Q: When should you communicate your intention to leave the roundabout?
A: You should prioritise control but can signal left to indicate your intention when needed.

Position:

Q: What position should you ride in when negotiating the roundabout?
A: Primary position (‘Follow me’ position) is important to prevent hazardous overtaking.

Q: As you approach this multi-lane roundabout, which lane should you use if you are turning left at the first exit? What about for straight ahead? Which lane is best for turning right using the third exit?
A: For the first or second exits, primary position in the left-hand lane is normally suitable. For the third exit, the right-hand lane is normally preferrable. Sometimes a painted line or sign will indicate which lane you should be in.

title: How could you support your riders in this scenario?
displayTitle: How could you support your riders in this scenario?
body: You and another instructor are working with four riders. The training area includes a large multi-lane junction. The riders haven’t ever negotiated a junction of that size and complexity before, and two of them appear nervous.
instruction: Enter your notes in the boxes below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content:
Your notes have been saved!

Here are some suggestions to compare your ideas with:
  • First, discuss the junction from the roadside to ensure the riders understand all the relevant instructing points. Your co-instructor can perform a demonstration of the activity at the same time as you discuss the coaching points with the riders
  • when the riders are ready, you could first ride through the junction doubled up a single group – this helps build the riders’ confidence
  • you could then progress the activity by splitting the group into two so that you and your co-instructor each support two riders, with each group not riding too close to each other. This creates opportunities for all the riders to experience riding at the front
  • the more nervous riders can each be paired with a more confident rider, who they can follow initially, before they advance to riding at the front themselves when ready – this differentiated and inclusive approach helps all the riders develop their cycling

Three possible questions to ask your riders:

Q – What road position should you use at different points on this junction?
Q – How should you negotiate a change of lane?
Q – Thinking about the four key skills, how should you manage the relationship with other road users?

Scroll down to continue.

title: Using cycling infrastructure
body: Many riders use cycling infrastructure without considering its functionality. It is therefore important to make riders aware how useful the available infrastructure is to their journey and that using it is optional. You should discuss with your riders whether or not to use certain infrastructure, considering issues such as its width, length, position on the road, proximity to junctions and its overall condition.
instruction: Scroll down to continue.

title: • Some examples ...
body: There are many scenarios where you can cover this activity.
instruction: Select the ‘+’ button for some examples.

_items.content: Sampling good quality, segregated cycle lanes during training and pausing at certain points of the journey to discuss the potential benefits and disadvantages of using particular infrastructure.
Through activities where riders can cycle assertively and be coached, where appropriate, to dynamically move out of cycle lanes or to avoid poorly designed infrastructure altogether.
Activities that coach riders to avoid using cycle lanes that put them in a position contradictory to the National Standard, particularly in Give Way situations.
Activities where riders may use advanced stop lines (ASLs) at traffic-light-controlled junctions.
Using roads that have contraflow cycle lanes.

title: Evaluate this infrastructure
body: Take a look at these before and after images that show two examples of cycling infrastructure. Before moving to the second image at each site, spend a moment thinking about any potential issues with the infrastructure you see.
instruction: Select the arrow to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body: What potential issues do you see with the infrastructure?

_graphic.alt: Roundabout with a cycle lane

_items.body:
The use of this cycle lane puts riders in a secondary riding position, which can be hazardous as it can:

  • encourage road users behind to overtake as they enter the roundabout
  • invite road users to overtake and turn across riders on the roundabout itself
Riders should instead opt for the primary position in either the left-hand or right-hand lane, depending on which exit they wish to take.

_graphic.alt: Roundabout with a bus in the cycle lane

_items.body: What potential issues do you see with the infrastructure?

_graphic.alt: Cycle lane passing a side road and leading up to a road narrowing

_items.body:
This cycle lane leads riders close to a side road. The bend in the main road obstructs a person drivings’ view when they exit the side road, leading them to creep forward.

As the cycle lane continues, it also invites riders to use the secondary position as they pass through a road narrowing up ahead, potentially leading to ‘close pass’ situations.

_graphic.alt: Cycle lane passing a side road and leading up to a road narrowing with the front of a car in the cycle lane

title: Check your understanding of infrastructure and ASLs
displayTitle: Check your understanding of infrastructure and ASLs
body: Now that you have watched the video, and considering the available cycling infrastructure in your area, can you answer the following questions?
instruction: Select ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ for each statement.

_items.stem: Do we always have to use the available cycling infrastructure?
If using a cycle lane, should we always ride in the middle of it?
Should we always use cycle lanes that lead up to ASLs?
Should we usually position ourselves in the primary position when waiting in ASLs?

_feedback.pass:
That is all correct – well done!

You've passed this quiz with a score of {0}%.

You will need to teach your riders that the use of cycling infrastructure is optional, and riders should only use infrastructure after reviewing its quality of design. Positioning in cycle lanes should be flexible and for conventional cycle lanes, it can sometimes be better for riders to position themselves on the right-hand side of them to improve visibility. When deciding which side to filter up to ASLs on, riders should not automatically use available cycle lanes such as those on the left-hand side of queuing traffic. Riders should first consider factors such as the available space, if there is time to reach the front, and whether queuing road users may be about to set off or turn. On reaching ASLs, the primary position is usually the most suitable position to wait in, since it ensures riders are clearly in view and are less likely to be overtaken when negotiating the junction.
_feedback.partialFail:
That is not quite right.

You scored {0}% please try again.

Have another go at the questions.
_feedback.fail:
That is still not quite right.

You scored {0}%.

You will need to teach your riders that the use of cycling infrastructure is optional, and riders should only use infrastructure after reviewing its quality of design. Positioning in cycle lanes should be flexible and for conventional cycle lanes, it can sometimes be better for riders to position themselves on the right-hand side of them to improve visibility. When deciding which side to filter up to ASLs on, riders should not automatically use available cycle lanes such as those on the left-hand side of queuing traffic. Riders should first consider factors such as the available space, if there is time to reach the front, and whether queuing road users may be about to set off or turn. On reaching ASLs, the primary position is usually the most suitable position to wait in, since it ensures riders are clearly in view and are less likely to be overtaken when negotiating the junction.

title: Being aware of driver blind spots and sharing bus lanes
displayTitle: Being aware of driver blind spots and sharing bus lanes
body:
Driver blind spots is an essential training topic, which you can discuss at all on-road environments that have traffic, including bus lanes. The topic relates closely to the need for riders to ‘create and maintain a safe riding space’ through frequently observing and communicating with other road users, while adopting suitable riding positions to stay visible to others.

Bus lanes can enable riders to safely bypass more congested lanes of traffic, as certain road users are not permitted to use them at particular times. However, sharing bus lanes with vehicles such as buses or taxis can pose some additional hazards (such as when buses pull in or out up ahead), so riders need to learn strategies for using them.

If there are no bus lanes or bus stops in the training area, it can still be helpful to discuss the topic of how to share space with vehicles that pull in or out up ahead such as taxis, delivery vehicles or vehicles using parking spaces.
instruction: Scroll down to continue.

title: Driver blind spots
body: It is important to anticipate and be aware of when you as a rider may be in a driver’s blind spot and what to do to ensure you are seen. Here are a selection of images that show different driver blind spots.
instruction: Select the arrow for examples of potential blind spots.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrow for examples of potential blind spots.

_items.body:
Directly in front of vehicles that have high cabins. Higher cabins can make it difficult for lorry drivers to see what is in front of them. Adopting the primary position sufficiently in advance of junctions can help riders stay in sight.

The space to the front left or right of higher vehicles. Many higher cabins have restricted views due to the windshield pillars.

The space up alongside lorries; riders should avoid putting themselves alongside larger vehicles that may be about to turn at junctions. The vehicles require a longer turning circle and may swing in or out when turning.

Lorry drivers may be unable to see what is directly behind, so riders should not position themselves directly behind if the vehicle may be about to reverse.

Many vans do not have rear windows or windscreens, so riders should take care around these blind spots.

Vans are widely used as delivery vehicles, so riders should be prepared for such vehicles to suddenly stop, pull in or out, or reverse.

Buses regularly pull in and out and may have blind spots at the sides and rear. If waiting behind vehicles with blind spots, riders may choose to wait where they can see and be seen in drivers’ wing mirrors. Riders should never filter up the inside of buses that may be about to pull in.

All cars have blind spots. In some situations, drivers may park in a position that requires them to reverse or pull out with limited visibility. This may be common where there are driveways, car parks or areas with shops, where riders should stay alert, give drivers plenty of space and be prepared for the unexpected.
In rural settings, agricultural vehicles like tractors will have various blind spots, particularly when towing. Riders should give such vehicles plenty of space.

title: Awareness of blind spots
body: How can you get riders thinking about potential blind spots?
instruction: Select each image to find out more.

_items.leftAlt: An instructor pointing out a bus to a rider
_items.rightText: Draw riders’ attention to the various types of blind spots that may be seen from the roadside such as those for heavy goods vehicles, buses, vans and cars. You can also discuss them when buddy riding on the move.
Consider sharing visual images (such as photos) of particular blind spots.

Discuss relevant locations where blind spots are a particular issue, for example at:
  • wider junctions where larger vehicles may swing in when turning left
  • multi-lane junctions or roundabouts where it is essential to adopt the primary riding position to prevent hazardous overtaking
  • locations with car parking spaces where drivers reverse out despite limited visibility

title: Bus lanes
body: We’re now going to look at the topic of sharing space with buses and using bus lanes. Watch this video and answer the questions on the screen?

title: • Questions ...

_message.content: Your notes have been saved! Compare your thoughts with the suggestions below. Scroll down to continue.

_items.question: What riding position should riders normally use when riding in bus lanes?
What position can the rider take to enable the bus driver in front to see them?
How might the rider know if the buses are about to pull out?
How might the rider know if the bus ahead is about to pull in?
How much space should the rider give when overtaking the bus?

title: Good practice for cycling in bus lanes
displayTitle: Good practice for cycling in bus lanes
body: Here are some important coaching points on how to cycle in bus lanes and what to do if buses or other road users ahead pull in or out.
instruction: Scroll down to find out more.

_items.title: Riding position
_items.body:
When cycling in a bus lane where there is insufficient space for a bus to overtake, use the primary riding position.

Should other road users behind catch up with you and have the desire and space to overtake, communicate with them through eye contact and consider moving into the secondary position to give them space to overtake.

_items.title: Catching up with slower riders
_items.body: On catching up with slower riders who are cycling in the secondary position, give them plenty of space, particularly if passing them.

_items.title: Catching up with a bus
_items.body:
On catching up with a bus that has slowed for traffic in front, be sure not to ride too close and consider adopting a position that enables the bus driver to see you in their wing mirror.

Consider if the bus is about to pull in to stop; you may see brake lights, indicators or a bus stop with a queue of people waiting.

_items.title: Passing a bus
_items.body:
On approaching a bus ahead that is pulling in or has stopped, look behind and communicate with any road user behind with eye contact. When it is clear, move to the right-hand side of the bus lane.

Consider whether the bus might be about to pull out again. Look out for signs such as indicators flashing, or no-one else waiting at the bus stop.

Check again over the right shoulder and, when it is clear, move into the right-hand lane to overtake the bus.

If necessary, adopt the primary position to prevent hazardous overtaking and to give space to any pedestrians who may currently be out of sight and could cross the road in front of the bus. After passing the bus, look in front and behind over the left shoulder and, if clear, move back into the bus lane and into a suitable riding position to continue the journey.

instruction: Select the forward arrow to return.

title: Riding on roads with a speed limit above 30mph
displayTitle: Riding on roads with a speed limit above 30mph
body:
There are different scenarios where riders will encounter other road users travelling faster than 30mph. These include:

  • rural country lanes, that have a variety of lane widths and visibility
  • busy A-roads or single or dual carriageways between different towns including roads with the national speed limit
  • ring roads or by-passes
  • urban or suburban roads with speed limits of up to 40 or 50mph
As with all advanced on-road activities, it is important you introduce your riders to these environments progressively and in a rider-centred manner.
instruction: Scroll down to continue.

title: • Short film ...
body: Watch this short film of a rider cycling on some faster and rural roads and then write down below some important things to discuss with your riders on how they should cycle in these environments.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video.

title: What will you discuss with your riders?
displayTitle: What will you discuss with your riders?
instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content: Your notes have been saved! Compare your thoughts with the suggestions below. Scroll down to continue.

_activity.title: What will you discuss with your riders?

_items.question: What would your coaching points be for supporting riders to use faster roads?

title: • Discussion points ...
instruction: Select the ‘+’ button to find out what these are.

_items.content: Think about how to increase your visibility to other road users who are moving quickly. Consider when to take primary position and make sure you carry out good and frequent observations.
When cycling around corners on rural roads, primary position is usually preferrable to make you more visible and to prevent hazardous overtaking.
People driving should overtake you with a safe passing distance of more than 1.5 metres on roads above 30mph.
Use your discretion to choose your road position. Be flexible and make sure you are visible. It may not always be possible to move out to primary position and sometimes a dynamic position is needed.

“When cycling on the road, your riding position is a dynamic choice. This means that you change it according to the circumstances. Your riding position should be flexible and based on a range of factors. These include the space available and the physical nature of the on-road environment, the width of the lane and the width of your cycle. They also include the speed that you are cycling and the size and speed of other road users around you.”

(Ride Guide, page 24)

instruction: Select the forward arrow to return.

title: Risk benefit assessment
body:
RBA is covered in detail in Module 4 of the Level 2 Award in Instructing Cycle Training and in the Cycle Training Delivery Guide. You can also access The Bikeability Trust’s Risk Management Guidance under the Resources tab.

During all training, but especially in more complex and busier situations, your riders need to be centrally involved in the RBA process. Discussions on topics of risk are an essential part of their training and will support your riders to anticipate and respond to hazards in, or changes to, the environment in which they are cycling.

Let us look at a few different RBA scenarios.
instruction: Scroll down to continue.

title: Planning a longer distance
body: You are supporting a rider to plan a journey that will integrate part of their future commute to and from work. During the planning exercise, you discover that the journey is longer than was expected, and you are concerned that the rider may struggle with the distance. The rider is unable to attend another session after this one.
instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

title: How would you manage this situation?

_message.content:
Your notes have been saved!

Here are some suggestions to compare with yours:
  • prompt the rider to bring a drink or snack along to the session and plan breaks in the journey at specific places of interest on the route
  • regularly check in with the rider to see how they are feeling at various points during the session
  • deliver the session in more of a continuous buddy-riding format as this will enable as much of the future commute to be ridden as possible
  • consider back-up route options in case it is not possible to reach the destination

Scroll down to continue.

_activity.title: Planning a longer distance
_activity.body: You are supporting a rider to plan a journey that will integrate part of their future commute to and from work. During the planning exercise, you discover that the journey is longer than was expected, and you are concerned that the rider may struggle with the distance. The rider is unable to attend another session after this one.

_items.question: How would you manage this situation?

title: Concerns about speed
body: Prior to working with a rider, you carry out an on-road survey of an area to be used for independent riding exercises. The rider is building their fitness through cycling but currently struggles to ride at higher speeds. The speed differential between the rider and other traffic is much higher than expected, and you are concerned that this could put your rider at excessive risk. How could you manage this situation?
instruction: Select the arrow for potential solutions.

_items.body: Carry out continued formative assessment of the rider’s cycling during the initial, less complex activities and then reassess their readiness to cycle at the sites with faster traffic.

Prompt the rider to use their gears more and to switch between primary and secondary riding positions at appropriate moments. Remind them to consider the space and time available and speed of other road users. You can also make the rider aware that cycling at lower speeds can make it harder to adopt the primary position.
If deciding to ride in the area, to provide them with buddy-riding support to help manage the risk.
If, after further assessment of the rider’s cycling, you still deem the sites to be too complex, use an alternative back-up location.

title: Promoting rider independence while managing risk
displayTitle: Promoting rider independence while managing risk
body: You are working with one rider who is attempting an exercise where they ride straight ahead through a junction controlled by traffic lights. The rider wants to attempt the activity alone as the junction will be part of their future commute to work.
instruction: Enter your notes in the box below and select ‘Save’. Your ideas will be exported to your PDF course notes for you to download at the end of this module.

_message.content:
Your notes have been saved!

Compare your ideas with these potential solutions:
  • if you assess the rider as not yet ready to attempt the activity on their own, you could offer to support them by buddy riding with them for their first attempt(s)
  • you could then potentially progress the activity by cycling further behind the rider to create a more independent riding experience
  • when you and the rider assess that they are ready to attempt the exercise more independently, you could, where possible, adopt a dynamic position on the pavement, supporting them where needed by being positioned near to the points of highest risk (for example, between the brow of the hill and the junction itself)

Scroll down to continue.

_activity.title: Promoting rider independence while managing risk
_activity.body: You are working with one rider who is attempting an exercise where they ride straight ahead through a junction controlled by traffic lights. The rider wants to attempt the activity alone as the junction will be part of their future commute to work. The activity involves attempting to move into the primary position in advance of the junction, and there are sight-line issues due to the brow of a hill near the start.

_items.question: How might you support the rider to carry out this exercise independently while managing the risk?

title: Dealing with abusive road users
body: During a buddy-riding journey, your riders are verbally abused and beeped at by a driver who passes them very closely on a road that has a 40mph speed limit. The riders appear flustered. How would you deal with this situation?
instruction: Selecteach card for ideas from instructors of possible ways to handle this scenario.

_front.alt: An icon showing riders in a neater formation

_back.content: Ask the group to pull in at a suitable moment and discuss the benefits of (and potential issues with) maintaining a strong road position.

_front.alt: An icon showing a worried to a happy face

_back.content: Check in with riders to ensure that cycling activities only resume once riders have calmed down and are ready.
Suggest that the riders adopt a more positive and interactive approach to sharing the road with the next road users they encounter. This is likely to rebuild confidence.
Discuss the relevant Highway Code rules with the group to ensure they are aware of their rights and all road users’ responsibilities.

_front.alt: An icon of pen and paper

_back.content: Consider whether it is necessary to note down vehicle details to report the incident.

title: Summary
body:
Well done! You have now completed the main content for this advanced on-road cycle training module and should have developed your knowledge and understanding of:

  • why advanced on-road training is so important
  • how advanced on-road cycling relates to the National Standard for Cycle Training and The Bikeability Trust delivery guidance
  • how to assess riders’ readiness for advanced on-road training and how to transition into more complex activities
  • how to build rider confidence for cycling in advanced on-road environments
  • various strategies for delivering effective training
  • specific advanced on-road training activities and some of the important instructing points to cover
  • good practice considerations such as those around RBA and inclusive training

title: What’s next?
body:
Congratulations! You have completed this training module.

It’s soon time for you to put into practice what you have learnt. You can work alongside an experienced instructor to do this or look out for practical continuing professional development opportunities from your training provider or recognised delivery centre.

You can access the documents or links referred to in the module by selecting the Resources tab on the top right-hand side of the screen.

Remember that your development as an instructor and rider never stops, and you will need to continue to evolve and stay up to date. This will ensure that you deliver the very best training possible to your riders!

You can download your certificate on the next page.
